list_page_teaser: Spoiler Alert!  Even though this Gallery has only a couple of images, spoilers lurk on this page!  If you haven't yet seen the prequel trilogy, do not click!
description_html:
This gallery contains spiritual portraits of the main characters in the Star Wars Prequel Trilogy.

To see the personalities of main characters in the original trilogy, see the original trilogy gallery on this site. To see the personalities of some Jedi Masters and droids, see the Jedi Masters and droids gallery.
story_html:
These images show how Anakin ends up caught between Padme and Palpatine.

The Red in Padme's image shows she's emotional — and stands in opposition to the Green in Anakin's image, that represents his preference for logic. Similarly, the Blue in her portrait shows she's idealistic — and stands in opposition to the Yellow in Anakin's portrait, that represents his realistic outlook.

These opposites in Padme's and Anakin's personalities fuel a powerful attraction. Meanwhile, the plethora of Green in Palpatine's extreme image shows he is very logical, but has few ideals and little capacity for empathy.

Although Anakin and Palpatine have similar personalities, Skywalker's preferences are much less extreme than those of Darth Sidious. In other words, the images show that Palpatine has even less in common with Padme and the Jedis than Anakin has.

To learn more about a character's personality, click on their thumbnail to see a larger version, then click on the Show the Whole Story button to read the character's story.

image_list.title: Padme Amidala
image_list.subtitle_html: Queen Padme Amidala of Naboo
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Blue represents Padme's idealism, the Red her Feeling and concern for the well-being of others.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Padme's dominant trait, her concern for others.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  She demonstrates this trait in her dedication to public service and desire for the health, happiness, and well-being of all people.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Padme's auxiliary trait, her idealism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She demonstrates this trait in her desire to find peaceful solutions to conflict arising from differing opinions.
image_list.story_intro_html:
My favorite scene from all three movies was of Padme and Anakin having a picnic in a meadow on Naboo. You could tell they were very much in love. I guess I'm just an old softie.

About This Portrait

This spiritual portrait is based on the Star Wars Prequel Trilogy:

  • Episode I: The Phantom Menace
  • Episode II: Attack of the Clones
  • Episode III: Revenge of the Sith

The book Star Wars Psychology: The Dark Side of the Mind, by Travis Langley and with a forward by Carrie Goldman, was also helpful in creating these portraits. This excellent book is a collection of immensely entertaining and enlightening essays and if you are a fan of Star Wars, I recommend it highly!

image_list.title: Anakin Skywalker
image_list.subtitle_html: Jedi Knight and Darth Vader
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Yellow represents Anakin's pragmatism.  In addition to lacking Padme's idealism, the Green shows he's more concerned about efficiency than the well-being of others.  Dun-dun-dunnnn!!!  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Anakin's dominant trait, his pragmatism.  In Introverts, the dominant function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  This trait is evident in Anakin's superior ability to pilot all types of flying craft.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Anakin's auxiliary trait, his rationality.  In Introverts, the auxiliary function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  This trait is evident in Anakin's ability to kill others, ultimately without feeling any remorse whatsoever.
image_list.story_intro_html:
I believe we have all felt anguish similar to Anakin's, torn between our heads and our hearts. It brings to mind the anguish Thomas Jefferson felt when he met Maria Cosway.

About This Portrait

This spiritual portrait is based on the Star Wars Prequel Trilogy:

  • Episode I: The Phantom Menace
  • Episode II: Attack of the Clones
  • Episode III: Revenge of the Sith

The book Star Wars Psychology: The Dark Side of the Mind, by Travis Langley and with a forward by Carrie Goldman, was also helpful in creating these portraits. This excellent book is a collection of immensely entertaining and enlightening essays and if you are a fan of Star Wars, I recommend it highly!

image_list.title: Sheev Palpatine
image_list.subtitle_html: Emperor and Darth Sidious
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Sheev Palpatine's spiritual portrait shows he is extremely logical and decisive.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Sheev Palpatine's dominant personality trait, his realism.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  Palpatine demonstrates this trait in the way he forsakes all ideals in his quest for absolute and total power over everyone in the galaxy, focusing all of his attention on his single, ambitious goal.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Sheev Palpatine's auxiliary personality trait, his very strong preference for logic.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  Palpatine demonstrates this trait in the way he shows no emotion, except perhaps a perverse gleefulness, when commanding that people, and even entire civilizations, be murdered.
image_list.story_intro_html:
Unlimited Power!

The Green in Sheev Palpatine's image shows he is extremely decisive. He is so decisive, in fact, that he wants to be in charge of making decisions for everyone in the entire galaxy.

At one point Palpatine gives Anakin Skywalker some insight into the fine line between good and evil, and right and wrong:

Good is a point of view, Anakin. The Sith and the Jedi are similar in almost every way, including their quest for greater power.
 — Supreme Emporer Palpatine in Star Wars Episode III: The Revenge of the Sith (2005).

Later, Anakin finds Palpatine and Master Windu engaged in a light saber fight. Unable to resist Palpatine's pleas, Anakin intervenes just as Master Windu prepares to deal a fatal blow to Palpatine.

Supreme Chancellor Palpatine: Please don't.
Anakin Skywalker: No! [Cuts off Windu's arm before he can deliver the blow.]
Master Windu: [Screams in pain.]
Palpatine: Power! [Starts killing Windu with Sith lightning.] Unlimited power! [Sighs.]
Anakin: What have I done?
Palpatine: You're fulfilling your destiny, Anakin. Become my apprentice. Learn to use the dark side of the Force.
Anakin: I will do whatever you ask.
Palpatine: Good.
 — From Star Wars Episode III: The Revenge of the Sith (2005).

About This Portrait

This spiritual portrait is based on the Star Wars Prequel Trilogy:

  • Episode I: The Phantom Menace
  • Episode II: Attack of the Clones
  • Episode III: Revenge of the Sith

The book Star Wars Psychology: The Dark Side of the Mind, by Travis Langley and with a forward by Carrie Goldman, was also helpful in creating these portraits. This excellent book is a collection of immensely entertaining and enlightening essays and if you are a fan of Star Wars, I recommend it highly!
